title: Slow start has Calgary Flames shuffling the deck in search of a spark | Flames |
text:
This is what happens when you open the season with one win in six outings.
This is what follows when you allow twice as many goals as you score to follow up a year of unforeseen momentum with embarrassing efforts in front of the hometown crowd.
Fans start to grovel, the media start to finger-point, players get on edge and things start to snowball.
Rumours start to fly.
Management did its part to try breaking the cycle following the Calgary Flames' fourth-straight loss at the Dome by putting goalie Karri Ramo on waivers Wednesday. No bites from the other 29 teams on the Flames' US$3.8-million free-agent signing, so off he goes to the AHL's Stockton Heat.
In hindsight, the surprise summer signing sure seems like a major mistake by GM Brad Treliving but surely he felt he was adding depth to the most important position while also giving the club options on the trade market.
As it turns out, the market wasn't and isn't there for either Jonas Hiller or Ramo, and the distraction/mess of having three goalies on the roster needed to be addressed.
Had the Flames opened the season well, like last year, the trio could theoretically have remained intact much longer but the horrific start brought too much attention to the situation and certainly didn't help anyone's performance.
Treliving insists they "have a plan" for how Ramo is going to share the net in Stockton with the franchise's goalie of the future, Jon Gillies. It shall be interesting as conventional wisdom suggests the young college stud should get 75% of the starts, which could/should/would prompt Ramo to eventually ask for a European assignment instead. Then again, he may even be back here again.
Flames head coach Bob Hartley is still at least one game away from trying to shake things up in net as he insists on starting Jonas Hiller over Joni Ortio Friday against the Detroit Red Wings.
We will undoubtedly see Ortio make his season debut on the Flames' tough three-game road trip to New York, Brooklyn and Ottawa.
The Dougie Hamilton Experience sure hasn't lived up to the hype as of yet, prompting Hartley to rightfully switch up his blueline pairings to Mark Giordano/Dennis Wideman, Kris Russell/Deryk Engelland and Hamilton with either Ladislav Smid or call-up Jakub Nakladal.
They sorely miss T.J. Brodie, who will make the trip and potentially suit up after breaking his hand in the preseason.
Make no mistake, the whole "sky is falling" attitude most fans in this city have is completely warranted given how important a good start is and how horrifically outplayed the Flames have been.
The work ethic that was the team's calling card isn't there and the breakdowns are stunningly constant.
With concerns the season is already in jeopardy, you will start to hear more and more trade rumours as the notoriously hard-working Treliving contemplates doing what he can to help get things back on track.
Fact is, the answer lies in the dressing room with the lads who are capable of so much more.
Still, talk of trading Wideman to potentially open up money to sign Russell will persist as will speculation about the future of Jiri Hudler, who can't possibly be here next year given his pricetag will be in the $7-million range thanks to an eighth-place finish in NHL scoring last year.
If things continue to slide here, you can bet "Huds" will be traded before the trade deadline.
Sportsnet's Mark Spector sure stirred the pot by suggesting Treliving and Tampa Bay Lightning GM Steve Yzerman have had talks about pending free agent Steve Stamkos, prompting many to start piecing together fantasy trades involving the Lightning ace for Wideman, Hudler, Sam Bennett or even Sean Monahan.
The inordinate number of scouts at recent Flames games only fuels the fire.
Perhaps we got a glimpse of the future as Hartley made the rare move of taking Hudler off the top line Tuesday to see how Michael Frolik fared alongside Johnny Gaudreau and Monahan.
Frolik has been rock solid, as advertised.
Bennett has not, and neither has Micheal Ferland.
It is early and there's little doubt those two youngsters will get better, as will the rest of the team.
Frankly, things couldn't really get much worse around here.
Or could they?
